ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Nanoindentation study of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Advanced Metallic Materials

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper, Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass has been studied by nanoindentation. Three different ways for nanoindentation tests were employed. Load-control nanoindentation was used to investigate the effect of the loading rate on the hardness and Young’s modulus. Young’s modulus of the specimen shows a loading rate dependence. The constant-load indentation creep measurement was performed. The creep data were fitted with the generalized Kelvin model, and the compliance spectrum and retardation spectrum were derived. Furthermore, the storage compliance and loss compliance were also discussed. For characterizing the change of the hardness and Young’s modulus with increasing indentation depth, depth-control nanoindentation analysis was conducted. The results show that both the hardness and Young’s modulus decrease with nanoindentation depth.

Section1.Heading: Introductions
Section1.Para: Nanoindentation of bulk metallic glasses has been performed in the past decade. Burgess et al. reported the effect of loading rates on the serrated flow of bulk metallic glass during nanoindentation and proposed that changes to flow serration did not represent a distinct physical phenomenon but rather the increasing irresolvability of displacement bursts [6]. By studying the loading rate effect on inelastic deformation in bulk metallic glass, Lee et al. revealed a proportional behavior of the indented volume to the loading rate, and they think that the enhanced inelastic deformation at high loading rate could be explained with dense shear bands [7]. The effect of the strain rates on the mechanical properties of bulk metallic glass has also been reported [8, 9]. In addition, nanoindentation creep is also an important and interesting subject in the research field of bulk metallic glasses [10–13]. Obviously, nanoindentation has played a major role in this field.

In this paper, we aim to evaluate the mechanical properties of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 with nanoindentation. We have not conducted this work on this bulk metallic glass in our previous work. The effects of loading rates and the maximum load on Young’s modulus and the hardness were discussed. Moreover, indentation creep was also investigated. More importantly, we firstly researched the storage and loss compliance of bulk metallic glasses.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para: The preparation of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass has been described in our recent report [5]. The typical procedure is as follows: an ingot with the nominal composition of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 was prepared by arc melting of the highly pure elements under a Ti-gettered argon atmosphere. The ingot was remelted at least 4 times to ensure compositional homogeneity. A cylindrical rod with 3 mm diameter and 50 mm height was produced by suction casting into a copper mold. The specimens used for nanoindentation were cut from a cylindrical rod and mechanically polished to a mirror finish before nanoindentation experiments were carried out on an MTS Nano Indenter XP system at room temperature. A Berkovich tip with a nominal tip radius of 20 nm was used in all the indentation experiments and the initial machine calibration was carried out on a fused silica standard. Testing positions for nanoindentation were fixed along a trace with a radius of 0.8 mm with a center as specimen. At least six indentation tests were carried out for each condition. The details of the tests are as follows.
(1) Nanoindentation tests with the loading rates of 0.2, 0.4, and 1 mN/s were performed to the load limit of 16 mN and 100 mN, respectively.

(2) Indentation creep tests were loaded, respectively, to 35 mN, 70 mN, 100 mN, and 150 mN with a loading rate of 5 mN/s, held for 1220 s, and then unloaded at the same rate as that during the loading.
(3) Nanoindentation tests with strain rate of 0.05 s−1 were carried out and the maximum depth of 1500 nm.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The typical displacement-load curves of the nanoindentation tests are shown in Figs. 1(a) and 1(c). It can be seen that the total displacement before unloading is approximately equal for all three loading rates at the corresponding maximum load. Nevertheless, differences can be observed in the unloading curves. Oliver et al. have pointed out that Young’s modulus and the hardness of the specimen are correlated with the unloading process [14, 15]. Therefore, it is reasonable to suppose that Young’s modulus and the hardness of the as-cast alloy are different. Based on the Oliver–Pharr method [14, 15], we obtained the elastic modulus (E) and hardness (H) of the as-cast Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass (Figs. 1(b) and 1(d)). From Figs. 1(b) and 1(d), Young’s modulus of the specimen referring to a particular maximum load shows a loading rate dependence. Specifically, the Young modulus decreases with the increase of loading rates from 0.2 mN/s to 1 mN/s. It is worth to point out that the variation range of the Young modulus at the maximum load of 16 mN is larger than that at 100 mN. However, the hardness of the specimen does not show a nearly constant value. For the compression of bulk metallic glasses, a larger number of net free volume is formed due to high loading rates, causing the coalescence of free volume [16]. Here, the free volume is defined as the excess volume compared to an ideal disordered atomic configuration of maximum density [17, 18]. Therefore, it is reasonable to suppose that atomic packing will be reduced due to the coalescence of free volume under the indenter. Sort et al. have assumed that reduced atomic packing causes the reduction of the reduced modulus (E
r ), due to enhancement of free volume in the region of material affected by the indentation impression [19]. Based on the relationship between the reduced modulus and Young’s modulus below [14]
1
$$ \frac{1}{E_{r}} = \frac{1 - \nu^{2}}{E} + \frac{1 - \nu_{i}^{2}}{E_{i}} $$ where υ is Poisson’s ratio for the specimen, and E
i and υ
i are the parameters of the indenter. We simplify Eq. (1) to
2
$$ E \propto E_{r} $$ Therefore, the reduction of Young’s modulus in the present work can also be interpreted by the reduced atomic packing and the enhancement of the free volume. In view of the constant value of the hardness, the inelastic/viscoplastic properties of bulk metallic glasses should be taken into account. Pang’s work has demonstrated that inelastic/viscoplastic properties are negligible at a loading rate higher than 0.1 mN/s, and plastic deformation cannot be fully developed, rendering the hardness constant [20]. As a consequence, the constant value of the hardness in the present work is interpretable and reasonable.
Fig. 1
Typical nanoindentation load-displacement curves (a, c), Young’s modulus and hardness (b, d) of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass

The shortcomings of conventional creep, usually referring to tensile creep, have been repeatedly exposed in previous work, e.g. requiring massive specimen and consuming much time [13, 21]. Hence, establishing reasonable models for studying the mechanism is a troublesome problem for scientific research using conventional creep tests, due to “sample-to-sample variations” in the microstructure [21]. Fortunately, an indentation creep technique has been developed and has come to be considered as an effective method for solving the aforementioned problems. The characteristic features of indentation creep can be described as regards three aspects as follows: (1) indentation creep is accompanied with constant force during the creep process, but the applied stress actually decreases due to the increasing contact area; (2) the region under the indenter is localized and microscopic, and a non-creep region remains surrounding the indentation sites during the experiments; (3) the indentation experiment cannot apply the step load [22].

To minimize the viscoelastic deformation during the loading segment, a high loading rate of 5 mN/s was chosen for indentation creep tests in the present work. Figure 2 shows load-displacement nanoindentation curves with different holding loads. A pronounced creep displacement can be observed during holding of the load segment. In addition, the total creep displacement decreases with increasing holding load. The creep displacement-holding time curves are shown in Fig. 3. According to the generalized Kelvin model, the viscoelastic behavior of bulk metallic glasses can be described with a series of dashpots and linear springs [22]. Using the model, the total creep displacement can be expressed as a function of holding time,
3
$$ h(t) = h_{e} + \sum_{i = 1}^{n} h_{i} \bigl(1 - e^{ - t/\tau_{i}} \bigr) + t/\mu_{0} $$ where h
e is the indentation depth at the first spring, h
i represents the indentation depth at the ith Kelvin element, μ 0 is a constant related to the viscosity coefficient of the last dashpot, and τ
i is the retardation time for the ith element. In view of the much simpler relaxation process in bulk metallic glasses [13], Eq. (3) is limited within two exponential terms. So, Eq. (3) could be rewritten as
4
$$ h(t) = h_{e} + h_{1} \bigl(1 - e^{ - t/\tau_{1}} \bigr) + h_{2} \bigl(1 - e^{ - t/\tau_{2}} \bigr) + t/\mu_{0} $$ The fitted curves derived from Eq. (4) are shown in Fig. 3, and the fitting parameters are summarized in Table 1. The values of τ 1 and τ 2 are different, indicating the influence of the amorphous structure on the indentation load [12, 13].
Fig. 2

Fig. 3

The creep compliance can be induced from the creep data, which can be described as
5
$$ J(t) = \frac{A_{0}}{P_{0}h_{\mathrm{in}}}\bigl(h_{e} + h_{1}\bigl(1 - e^{ - t/\tau_{1}}\bigr) + h_{2}\bigl(1 - e^{ - t/\tau_{2}}\bigr) + t/ \mu_{0}\bigr) $$ where A 0 and P 0 are the contact area and the applied load corresponding to the virtual length, h
in , which approximately equals the depth at the end of the loading. By introducing the parameters (Table 1) into Eq. (5), the dependence of the creep time on the creep compliance can be determined (Fig. 4). It can be clearly seen that the trend of all curves is approximately the same, initially constant and then increasing with time, due to the softened dispersion [12, 22]. The constant compliance is called J
g , which denotes the compliance when the material is in the glassy state. Hence J
g is also called the glassy compliance. The magnitude of J
g is equal to 10−10 Pa−1 for Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glasses. On the other hand, with the increase of the indentation depth, J(t) becomes larger, implying that the value of Young’s modulus (E) becomes smaller, because of the reciprocal relationship between creep compliance and Young’s modulus [12, 23]. More interestingly, creep compliance can be further used to derive the retardation spectrum (L(t)), which is a continuous spectrum of the retardation times [24], as follows:
6
$$\begin{aligned} L(t) =& \biggl[\biggl(1 + \frac{t}{\tau_{1}}\biggr)\frac{h_{1}}{\tau_{1}}e^{ - t/\tau_{1}} + \biggl(1 + \frac{t}{\tau_{2}}\biggr)\frac{h_{2}}{\tau_{2}}e^{ - t/\tau_{2}}\biggr] \\ &{}\times\frac{A_{0}}{P_{0}h_{in}}t\biggm|_{t = 2\tau} \end{aligned}$$
Fig. 4
Creep compliance spectra and retardation spectra of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass at different holding loads. (a) 35 mN, (b) 70 mN, (c) 100 mN, (d) 150 mN

The retardation spectra for different holding loads are also shown in Fig. 4. Each spectrum consists of two peaks, equal to the exponential terms, with well-defined relaxation times. This indicates two kinds of relaxation processes for the as-cast bulk metallic glasses during the indentation creep process [12, 13]. It is worth noticing that both the first and the second relaxation processes for the holding load of 35 mN are completed in a very short time, less than 50 s. By comparing the retardation spectra with each other, we find that the creep process at a holding load of 70 mN shows more relaxation than the others.

The creep compliance and retardation spectrum are useful data, which are often used for deriving other mechanical properties, such as storage compliance (J′) and loss compliance (J″) [22]. In general, storage compliance is defined as the strain in a sinusoidal deformation in phase with the stress divided by the stress, and loss compliance is defined as the strain 90° out of phase with the stress divided by the stress [25]. Here, the storage compliance (J′) and loss compliance (J″) can be described as [26]
7
$$\begin{aligned} &{J'(\omega ) = J_{g} + J_{1} \frac{1}{1 + \omega^{2}\tau_{1}^{2}} + J_{2}\frac{1}{1 + \omega^{2}\tau_{2}^{2}}} \end{aligned}$$
8
$$\begin{aligned} &{J''(\omega ) = J_{1}\frac{\omega \tau_{1}}{1 + \omega^{2}\tau_{1}^{2}} + J_{2}\frac{\omega \tau_{2}}{1 + \omega^{2}\tau_{2}^{2}} + \frac{1}{\eta_{0}\omega}} \end{aligned}$$ where J 1=h 1 A 0/P 0 h in; J 2=h 2 A 0/P 0 h in; η 0(=P 0 h in μ 0/A 0) is the steady-flow viscosity, which is the reciprocal of the steady-flow fluidity; ω=1/t. Figure 5 shows the plots of storage compliance and loss compliance as a function of ω. As shown, all curves of the storage compliance begin as a constant and then increase with time, which is in accord with the magnitude of the creep compliance. Nevertheless, the magnitude of the loss compliance is far lower than that of the storage compliance. In view of correlation between compliance and modulus, we can use Eqs. (7) and (8) to derive the storage modulus (E′) and the loss modulus (E″), of which Young’s modulus consists. The converse equation can be expressed as [25]
9
10
11
Combining Eqs. (9), (10), and (11), the relationships among J′, J″, E′, and E″ can be derived as follows:
12
$$ E' = \frac{J'}{J^{\prime2} + J^{\prime\prime2}},\qquad E'' = \frac{J''}{J^{\prime2} + J^{\prime\prime2}} $$
Fig. 5
Storage compliance and loss compliance spectra of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass at different holding loads. (a) 35 mN, (b) 70 mN, (c) 100 mN, (d) 150 mN

Based on Eq. (12), we argue that the storage modulus is far higher than the loss modulus for Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass. Consequently, Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass has a very excellent elastic-deformation capacity at room temperature. This may also be used to explain why Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass has a higher Young’s modulus than other Cu- or Zr-based bulk metallic glasses [27].

Previous work has revealed that the hardness and/or Young’s modulus of materials decreases as the indentation depth increases [28–30]. The hardness and Young’s modulus of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 after different holding loads of indentation creep tests are shown in Fig. 6. It indicates that both the hardness and Young’s modulus decrease with increasing indentation depth. The decrease of the hardness can be attributed to strain softening, because a free volume in metallic glasses can be created by the stress applied during nanoindentation [29, 31]. Moreover, the production of free volume reduced atomic packing and enhanced the atomic mobility, which led to decreasing Young’s modulus [29]. For further investigation of the effect of the indentation depth on Young’s modulus and the hardness of the as-cast bulk metallic glass, the depth-controlled nanoindentation measurement was conducted (Fig. 7). It can be clearly seen that the hardness decreases as the size of the indentation increases (Fig. 7(a)), consisting with the trend of hardness at different holding loads. We can also clearly see that Young’s modulus decreases with increasing depth (Fig. 7(b)), which is consistent with the result of the creep compliance results and the result of generalization by different holding loads (Fig. 6).
Fig. 6
Hardness and Young’s modulus after different holding loads
Fig. 7
Hardness (a) and Young’s modulus (b) versus indentation depth plots of Cu52Zr37Ti8In3 bulk metallic glass
